parse.title: List of countries with alcohol prohibition

text.*:
The following countries have or had comprehensive prohibitions against alcohol.

Present[edit]

Currently, alcohol prohibition is enforced in many Muslim-majority countries and some regions of India.[1]

  •  Afghanistan
  •  Bangladesh (excluding non-Muslims)
  •  Brunei
  •  India (prohibition in the states of Gujarat, Bihar, Nagaland, Manipur, and the union territory of Lakshwadeep. Legal in all other states and territories.)[2][3]
  •  Indonesia (prohibition in small business shops)[4]
  •  Iran
  •  Iraq
  •  Kuwait
  •  Libya
  •  Maldives (excluding non-Muslims)
  •  Mauritania
  •  Pakistan (excluding non-Muslims)
  •  Qatar (excluding non-Muslims)
  •  Saudi Arabia
  •  Somalia
  •  Sri Lanka (Purchasing and possessing liquor is prohibited for women. Alcohol consumption is legal in every other aspect.) [5]
  •  Sudan
  •  United Arab Emirates (prohibition in the emirate of Sharjah only)
  •  Yemen (legal in the areas of former communist South Yemen until 1994)

Past[edit]

This section does not cite any sources. Please help improve this section by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. (December 2015) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)
  •  United States – 1920–1933 (see prohibition in the United States)
  •  Canada – 1918–1920 (see prohibition in Canada)
  •  Faroe Islands – 1907–1992 (see Faroese alcohol referendum, 1907)
  •  Russian Empire and the  Soviet Union – 1914–1923
  •  Iceland – 1915–1935 (see prohibition in Iceland) – However beer with an alcohol content exceeding 2.25% was prohibited until 1989.
  •  Norway – 1916–1927
  •  Hungarian Soviet Republic – March 21 – August 1, 1919 – Sale and consumption of alcohol was prohibited.
  •  Finland – 1919–1932
  •  Pitcairn Islands
  •  North Yemen – 1962-1990

References[edit]

  1. ^ "Alcohol Prohibition in Foreign Countries". QuitAlcohol.com. Retrieved 2013-10-29. 
  2. ^ "States with total and phase-wise prohibition of alcohol in India". The Indian Express. 
  3. ^ "India's Bihar alcohol ban struck down". BBC News. Retrieved 18 May 2016. 
  4. ^ "Indonesia bans alcohol sales in small shops". BBC News. 
  5. ^ "Sri Lanka's president rejects move to allow women to buy alcohol". BBC News.
